this is the neighborhood where Kim have
been living with her Danish boyfriend
it's a really popular place for

but by global standards really safe
Kim was 30 she was from southern Sweden
and was four years into her career as a
freelance reporter she'd already had her
work published in The Guardian and the
New York Times and vice she loved to
travel and was about to move to China
with her boyfriend but first she had one
last story to finish this was from home
turf her birthplace was 45 minutes away
from here in Sweden and she was living
here so naturally she thought she was
safe it just never occurred to her that
something would happen here
Kim Val boarded a submarine built by
Pizza Madison a Danish inventor that
she'd been waiting to interview I could
imagine that she thought she was going
to have a fun ride she had told her
boyfriends that she was a little nervous
going under the ocean and but her
boyfriend said in court that he was
actually a little jealous and wanted to
come with her this is one of the last
photos of her alive police have
identified this as the route taken by
the submarine starting in the ER and
straight the waters between copenhagen
and southern sweden and then spending
time underwater around kerger bay the
next morning the submarines sank Peter
Madsen was rescued
without Kim the master was a geek that
was very interested from an early age to
create technical things his big dream
was to eventually end up making Denmark
you know a rockets producing nation he
just didn't care about anything else
so he was not so caring about you know
other people if they couldn't help him

just disappear Peter Madsen was arrested
soon after Kim was reported missing
later the remains of her dismembered

of course it they have had a terrible
time
missing their daughter and then since

social the case has also deeply affected
Kim's friends many of whom were

mind-boggling that her life has also
become a myth and a story for how things
are for our livelihood for the work we
do so it's yeah I think everyone who
knows her personally especially women
journalists and make freelance
journalists - I would say we're all like
very much still processing what's
happened you know we're we're only
really beginning to to comprehend and to
understand what we ought to do because
you know it's a period of like really
intense reflection and and now we need
to see action
Kim vows friends and family have sets up
a foundation in her memory it's already
raised more than two hundred thousand
dollars to help support other female
journalists like Kim I think it's really
inspiring to see that we can champion
women in the mid sub you know what has
been one of the worst things ever to hit
women in journalism in this industry but
we could continue to keep moving forward
because to kind of like shrink inside
this or shrinking fears the opposite of
what Kim would have wanted is the
opposite of what is actually good for
our world
